rows.name: tip_text
rows.value: You can always find these tools in the @local.parent_centre

rows.name: title
rows.comments: For consistency with the other widgets, it would make sense if the title and help fit inside the widget frame.

rows.name: video_src
rows.comments: Needs option for full screen mode

rows.name: duration
rows.comments: default in minutes, can be set to seconds in parameter_list

rows.name: help
rows.comments:
should be type: help
In case of text pop-up, use value. If launching something else, use action_list

rows.name: activity_image_src
rows.comments: A workshop activity corresponds to a column in Figma. It typically consists of intro and content. It occasionally has an outro.

rows.name: intro_nav_buttons
rows.comments: completed | set_local:hide_content:false; completed | set_local:hide_intro:true; uncompleted | emit:uncompleted

rows.name: button_uncompleted
rows.comments:
default: set_properties
use extend_properties to add to an existing list of properties

rows.name: content_box
rows.comments:
Do this row when include_outro = TRUE
!@local.include_outro

rows.name: content_box
rows.comments:
Do this row when include_outro = FALSE
@local.include_outro

rows.name: title
rows.value: title for sheet 1 was overwritten twice

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: These tools can help you remember what you've learnt this week.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: You could try and put some of what you've learnt in this workshop into practice this week!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let's listen to an audio together!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: It's time to learn and practice!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: It's time to learn and practice together!

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value:
You are a star! 

Today, also remember to RECOGNISE something you have done well, and REWARD yourself with something that makes you happy. You matter.

rows.name: outro_habit_text
rows.value: Every time you do a relax, mark your @local.parent_point to track your success.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let's talk about how your home practice went last week.

rows.name: text
rows.value: Each person say how this week’s home practice was for them. What went well? What was difficult? Remember to encourage and praise each other for trying!

rows.name: text
rows.value: We often have challenges with home practice. Let’s support each other! Think together about possible ways of solving each other’s challenges. It is so good to share problems and help each other as a team.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: You can use the top challenges and solutions that parents have.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let's start with caring for you.

rows.name: text
rows.value:
Can each of you say how you are feeling today? 

Each of you think of one thing that every person in your group have done well this week, and praise them for it.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: It's great to see you again!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Well done! See you next week!

rows.name: nav_template_list
intro_text
rows.value: This is the introduction text of the welcome together.

rows.name: nav_template_list
nav_template_list
rows.comments: w_1on1_welcome_individual; w_1on1_care_together; w_1on1_relax; w_1on1_intro; w_1on1_think; w_1on1_tools_activity;  w_1on1_home_practice; w_1on1_ending

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: This week is about spending one-on-one time with your teen.

rows.name: text
rows.value:
Being a parent can be so hard. Sometimes it feels like our children never listen to us.

But science shows that spending just a few minutes each day of focused one-on-one time with your teen helps build trust and love.

It’s a time when you focus on them, without TV or phones. Let them lead what you do or talk about.

rows.name: text
rows.value:
Talk together about ways to spend one-on-one time with your teen.

Feel like you have NO TIME and you are exhausted? Remember to also think of ways that don't take up extra time.

rows.name: button_info
rows.comments:
Walking to the shops
Get water together 
Doing a chore together 
Prepare dinner 
Eat breakfast/lunch/dinner 
Have tea after school 
Watch a T.V. show  
Review homework 
Chat before bedtime 
Play a game/sport

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: It may not have instant results, but it will make a difference over the long term. You are an amazing parent for trying this.

rows.name: outro_habit_text
rows.value: Every time you do one-on-one time, mark your @global.parent_point to track your success

rows.name: subtitle_1
rows.value: Try to do it every day

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Find 5 minutes (or more!) each day when your teen does not have something else they want to do. .

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first, but will come to enjoy this time with you!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Switch off TV and put aside phones. Look at your teen. Nod or say “I see” to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

rows.name: bottom_text
rows.value: One-on-one time with your teen can be fun for you, too! It might even make you feel less stressed.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: This week, can you try 5 minutes of one-on-one time with your teen every day that you can?

rows.name: habit_text
rows.value: Every time you do one-on-one time, mark your @global.parent_point to track your success

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: You can use the top 8 challenges and solutions that parents have with praise.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: This week is about positive instructions.

rows.name: slide_text_1
slide_text_2
rows.value:
DO NOT THINK ABOUT AN ELEPHANT 

What are you thinking about?

rows.name: slide_text_3
rows.value: ‘Don’t do’ instructions make teens think about that thing. Sometimes they don’t understand what we do want from them. Also often they hate being told not to do things (don’t we all?)

rows.name: slide_text_4
rows.value:
THINK ABOUT A FURRY TIGER, THANK YOU! 

What are you thinking about?

rows.name: slide_text_5
rows.value: Positive, clear instructions help teens focus on what they should be doing. They also feel more respectful to a teenager.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: This happened with @global.w_instruct_teen_girl and her @global.w_instruct_female_caregiver the other day:

rows.name: slide_text_1
rows.value:
@global.w_instruct_female_caregiver was cleaning the house while @global.w_instruct_teen_girl was with her friends practicing dance moves.

@global.w_instruct_female_caregiver: “Don’t make such a mess while I am cleaning the house. You are in the way!”

rows.name: slide_text_2
rows.value:
@global.w_instruct_teen_girl: “But I need to practice for the school competition. You never let me do anything.”

@global.w_instruct_female_caregiver: “Don’t you talk back to me!”

rows.name: slide_text_3
rows.value:
@global.w_instruct_teen_girl: “Arrg!! Why Am I being yelled at all the time????.”

(inside) @global.w_instruct_female_caregiver to herself: “That child is always making trouble.”

rows.name: discussion_text
rows.value:
How do you think @global.w_instruct_teen_girl felt about the way @global.w_instruct_female_caregiver responded?  

What could @global.w_instruct_female_caregiver have done differently?

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let's discuss what happened in this story.

rows.name: slide_text_1
rows.value: @global.w_instruct_female_caregiver was cleaning the house while @global.w_instruct_teen_girl was with her friends practicing dance moves.

rows.name: slide_text_2
rows.value:
@global.w_instruct_female_caregiver: “@global.w_instruct_teen_girl, it is nice to see you practicing your dance moves with your friends. Please take it outside so I can finish cleaning the house. Afterwards, you can show me your dance."

@global.w_instruct_teen_girl: “Okay, @global.w_instruct_female_caregiver!”

rows.name: slide_text_4
rows.value: @fields.w_instruct_female_caregiver: "Thank you for practicing outside while I finished cleaning the house, @fields.w_instruct_teen_girl . Now I have some time to watch your dance."

rows.name: slide_text_5
rows.value: @fields.w_instruct_female_caregiver: "Wow, @fields.w_instruct_teen_girl! You have such good dance moves!"

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Thank you for thinking along! Let’s go back in time and see what happens!

rows.name: discussion_text
rows.value:
Why do you think it worked better for @global.w_instruct_female_caregiver this time? 

What do you think worked well?

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let's discuss what happened this time.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Can your teen actually do what you are about to ask? It may be impossible for them to read quietly all day, but half an hour when you really need it is realistic.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Smile, look them in the eye and use positive words. Praise them as soon as they start to do what you ask!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Often we know what we want in our head, but we don’t say it clearly enough. Say exactly what you want them to do. Try ‘please come home by 7pm’ instead of ‘Come home in time’.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let's practice giving REAL, POSITIVE and CLEAR instructions.

rows.name: text
rows.value: Try giving positive instructions to each other! And give each other encouragement and praise – you deserve it.

rows.name: button_info
rows.comments:
This has to be authored as a pop-up text:

Example of a negative instruction: Please stop making that noise all the time! 

Examples of positive instructions: I like your music, but could you turn it down so that we can talk whilst we have dinner? Thank you – I really appreciate this. 
That’s great. Who is the singer? Please turn this off when you come in the house but you can play it in your room quietly if you want. Thank you!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value:
This week's home practice is to give your teen positive instructions.

Remember – GET REAL, GET POSITIVE, GET CLEAR = GET EXACTLY WHAT YOU WANT (as much as is possible with a teenager!)

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: It’s great to have you here.

rows.name: text
rows.value:
Parents don’t look after themselves enough. But this is so important. Reducing our stress and treating ourselves well helps us and our teenagers. 

Here are three brief things to do every day.

RELAX – RECOGNISE – REWARD

rows.name: slide_text_1
rows.value:
Say it aloud if you can "Well done for …"

Here is one thing we know you deserve a praise for -  you started using ParentApp!  
So... WELL DONE for using ParentApp! 

Here are more examples of things you might have done recently and deserve a praise: 

1. Showing love to my children 
2. Getting up even though I felt tired 
3. Smiling at someone 
4. Making food to stay strong 
5. Spending time with my children 
6. Helping my children with schoolwork

rows.name: slide_habit_text_1
rows.value: Every time you praise yourself, mark your @local.parent_point to track your success.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Take a moment and think of one thing YOU have done recently that you have done well!

__EMPTY_2: w_self-care_welcome_together; w_self-care_intro; w_self-care_relax;  w_self-care_recognise; w_self-care_reward;  w_self-care_tools_activity; w_self-care_home_practice; w_self-care_ending

rows.name: slide_text_1
rows.value:
What makes you happy? 

Have a hot drink 
Call a friend or family 
Have a relaxed bath 
Read 
Watch TV 
Write your own ____________ 

Taking care of yourself is an important parenting skill!  

Start now. Relax, recognise and reward yourself.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Remember you deserve your quality time too!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value:
Do a 30 second quick relaxation activity. Here's one: 
1. Close your eyes.   
2. Listen to your breath as it goes in and out five times, noticing how you feel.  
3. When you are ready open your eyes again. You are in control!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Take a moment and think of one thing YOU have done recently that you have done well! Say it aloud if you can "Well done for …"

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Remember you deserve your quality time too! What makes you happy?

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: This week's home practice is to relax, recognise and reward yourself.
